I've invested over 2000 hours into this game since 2018, and in 2024, I'm sharing this review as a cautionary message to the community.

This game used to be one of the best zombie survival experiences I've ever had. Scum drew me away from the Dayz universe with its straightforward crafting and base-building elements. I loved the simplicity and ease of looting various boxes, containers, puppets, and other players I encountered. The freedom to explore buildings and bunkers at my own pace was truly enjoyable. Over the past two years, I even went on to rent my own server, hosting up to 60 players.

Regrettably, the recent direction the developers have taken is bewildering. They introduced a convoluted cooking system and implemented an exhaustion mechanic that immobilizes you, forcing you to recuperate in bed. Crafting anything without gloves now results in numerous hand lacerations. They removed valuable content and replaced it with undesirable features. Server performance has declined, causing lag and rubber banding even with just one person present, worsened in full servers. Zombie spawns are erratic, with the new horde system leading to zombies appearing right in front of you or dropping from the sky. Clearing out a town or bunker becomes a futile effort as they respawn within ten minutes. The hordes are a formidable challenge, making the game unbearable for even seasoned players, let alone newcomers.

Regarding bunkers, instead of addressing lag and server stability, access has been restricted to mitigate stress on the servers. The last time the game felt enjoyable and stable was probably before they removed the old vehicles and introduced the new ones. I'm skeptical about the game improving; it seems to be heading towards increased confusion and bugs with each addition rather than addressing existing server issues. I didn't write this out of hatred for the game; it's actually my favorite, but it's currently in a dire state, and I don't foresee any improvement.

162967384.review:
To get one thing out of the way at the beginning: I love Scum (more than 1.5k hrs in it)
(My experience stems mostly from 2022 and the recent months)

The single most awesome thing about the game that has persisted until this day: The World with its different regions, points of interest, graphics and especially sounds which keep me immersed in the game to this day. I spend 2-3 weeks a year at the Croatian coast on holidays and this game enables me to extend my holidays even if i am not there. Terrific!

What has sadly always taken away from the game was the poor quality management of the developers and the server performances:
While patches were coming out constantly in 2022 they seem to have become much less frequent nowadays. The developers always focused on introducing new stuff first which in itself would not be bad, but  even the stuff they newly introduced hardly ever worked out of the box while at the same time breaking older stuff on top of that and not addressing or resolving long-standing issues. Hey it's early access! - oh how i've become to love that argument... after six years of early access. This is a question of development strategy and method and not a thing of early access per se. My best example to show a different and successful strategy would be Valheim: Their topmost priority has always been to get everything they have stable and only then introduce new things that have been tested on public test versions prior to patching them in. On top of that they let you host your own dedicated servers and give you the option to run the servers and the clients on older stable versions.
Now the server problem: Since I have been playing this game it has always struggled with server performance which is especially bad when in PVP but also problematic when in PVE. To this day servers seem to have to be restarted constantly (every 2 to 4 hours usually) as a "feature" to improve lags (!?) and server admins introduced a ton of restrictions on build elements or numbers of vehicles allowed on their servers per squad or player to combat poor server performance.

Which brings me to the reason I posted this review:
In a stroke of ingenuity the developers seem to have come up with a solution for one of the major reasons servers struggled with performance: A rework of the puppet/zombie system. Puppets and other forms of NPCs have been one of the main reasons why the game needed to communicate so much data to its players since dialling down on the amount of puppets on a server always significantly improved performance.
Back in 2022 the developers showed how to improve server performance from their end: They completely removed all the birds in the game never to be seen again. They were cute and I miss them... But their vanishing was not gamebreaking.
Now obviously they could not do this same move for the puppets or the rest of the animals so they came up with "improvements": A new much more exciting way to hunt animals: Follow clues to find them and only spawn them in after you followed those clues to the end. I have stumbled upon 2 or 3 animals which must have been spawned in by a bug or maybe someone had hunted them and not killed them before. But the world is dead in this respect, there are no more animals you can stumble upon while roaming the map.
A severe loss but still not completely gamebreaking.

But their greatest improvement is the new horde and dynamic spawn system. This ultimately completely kills the immersion in the game and breaks survival specific gameplay in every direction.
Up to the introduction to this incredible feature you could spot and snipe puppets from afar, or decide to evade them or even sneak in and kill them stealthily and they would be scattered around the whole map, especially around points of interest (makes sense...)
Now you have a completely puppet free map UNTIL you get to a POI, then they start spawning in right next to you. Mostly aggroing immediately, calling in more puppets while at it. Sniper rifles have become useless for killing puppets. Even if your teammate's presence spawns them in, you can only watch him combat invisible enemies if you are more than probably 30-50 meters away. Using handguns or rifles is often the only way to survive these sudden spawns while the shooting triggers even more to spawn in around you. And if you are in PVP you might as well invite other players in chat with your exact location to come kill you. Your only hope is that they have the same problem with puppets too...
This system is so absolutely broken. And I cannot think of any improvement to this system that could make it playable again. And the "coolest" thing: I don't really feel server performance has improved by much. More than 50 players and this game still rubber-bands, puppets and players are "teleporting" - stuff that has been the case before this system was introduced.

The developers do not seem to address this blunder when all they had to do was throw this system out again and start thinking of other ways to improve server performances. Even if server performance problems were completely solved now I would still absolutely prefer to have the old system back and simply play on a lower populated server to counter it. This spawn system completely kills the immersion and gameplay of this potentially awesome game that Scum was.
Puppets have to be visible if they are in line of sight, just like a player. They have to be finite for a time so you can clear an area. Anything else is completely unrealistic in a game that puts so much emphasis on realism.
 
Which is why I cannot recommend this game to any new player or anyone who is thinking about jumping back in after a longer hiatus like I did. Wait until they patch this out of the game - Otherwise I predict this game will fail just a few paces from the finish line...
So sad - But one can still hope

As a survival game this delivers, sometimes a little to much. Everything else is heavily lacking in thought, balancing, and content...and probably always will be. The horde mode is terrible, it makes using a gun (even silenced) a never end loop of zombie spawning even if you kill them all. The building mechanic has a LOT of flaws that make it awful and useless, people literally build in prefab buildings on the map because it's a better experience all around. For example, you can not build a wall on an upper floor without having a support or wall under it on EVERY floor and you can't build more then 2 floors out without needing another support. Also, did you build a wall i nthe wrong spot? Tough luck, break it and you risk losing half your building even if it has support elsewhere. It seems no one on the dev team has any experience with construction or consulted one because it is bad. You will be stuck with a 4x4 box in most cases unless you hate yourself. The hunting mechanic is tedious and a waste of time, its terrible allaround. Fishing is overly difficult unless you cheese it and there is no drag mechanic or fish tiring mechanic, which is why it is overly difficult. It's impossible to reel in a fish without using the cheese method. Some content isn't worth doing other then just to experience it once or twice, like raiding abandoned bunkers or fighting mechs. The cost/risk vs reward isn't balanced at all and probably never will be. And while we are on the topic of balance, the game still has a LOT of balancing issues when it comes to skills/stats and food/water consumption on top of some of it not making any realistic sense at all like crafting and building not helping with strength, constitution, or dexterity when it uses stamina. It just levels engineering and that is all. Plus the fact your intelligence is locked in and permanently goes down if you suicide is a real wtf were they thinking moment. I guess humans forgot how to learn in this universe. And the BIGGEST downside for me is that you can not run your own personal dedicated server. The devs make every excuse in the book for why they did this, but none of them hold any water. The biggest one is always "to keep people from developing online cheats" and pat themselves on the back because no one has made a health hack yet. What does that matter when you get 1 shot to the head from 1500m away by someone using an ESP aimbot combo? A quick google search pulls up plenty of free and paid multiplayer enabled cheats that work and are undetected because EAC is garbage. Either fix it or let us avoid it without having to shell out more money for some crappy company to host one for us. This is purely a cash grab move.

TLDR; This is just a 3D version of Project Zomboid but with a worse implementation and no dedicated server support. Playing with friends on a private server can be fun, but it is also frustrating a lot of the time, plus you have to pay for a server since you cant locally host a dedicated one for free...anything else isn't worth the time.

EDIT: For Dev Response

You can say you will fix everything in the world all you want, but the fact of the matter is that literally every aspect of this game has issues that make it a very unpleasant experience. I actually cut out 90% of my review because It was just complaining the whole time and I felt bad for anyone who might read it. I get that the game is in Early Access and still being flushed out, and if this was on a 0.2 patch or something I would have some faith in those words. But it isn't, it's 0.95, and if the backwards progress of previous patches are anything to go by I am not gonna hold my breath lol. You can't build garage doors or hangar doors on a foundation? Makes sense, not. No form of supporting upper floors that doesn't put a huge pillar in the way everywhere? Makes sense. A M249 suppressor gets completely annihilated from firing 1 mag? Makes sense. You get hit by a puppet and it stops your current action? Makes sense. I for one would stop pulling out my gun or sword if my life depended on it. Don't get me wrong, I like the game, but some things are in the game to literally piss the players off and I just can't for the life of me recommend it to anyone with design choices like that when they aren't even realistic design choices. Which brings me into why I can't, and wont recommend this game. The micromanagement of the dev team telling players how they can and can not play the game is what really puts me off. Even if this game gets flushed out properly, I still won't recommend it because a game by a dev team that refuses to implement basic options to let players play how they want will be a terrible experience for the vast majority of players. Disabling Mr. Brenner for example. Being told flat out "No, not gonna ever happen." because the dev team thinks they know better is messed up and any dev team like that I can not support. They may have an image in mind for how the game should be, but their are ZERO reasons to not allow these customization options if players want them, aside from arrogance or some twisted desire to annoy the players. An unkillable boss is fun, for about 10 minutes. Then players will find a way to cheese it because it is annoying, and that will get patched, then they find another method, and it gets patched, over and over again until it becomes a horrible experience and probably turns abandoned bunkers into unplayable content. Summary:
SCUM, yes this is an abbreviation for "Survival Combat United Masses", thrusts players into a challenging and gritty open world survival experience. Developed by Gamepires and Croteam, this game takes the survival genre to a higher level with a highly detailed metabolic system, realistic environments, and intense combat mechanics.

Gameplay:
SCUM excels at offering a deep and immersive survival experience. From regulating a character's metabolism to scavenging for resources and crafting essential items, every action feels essential to survival. The metabolic system adds an extra layer of realism, requiring players to monitor their character's calorie intake, hydration levels, and even vitamin balance. The game's expansive open world map provides plenty of opportunities for exploration and discovery, with a variety of landmarks, cities, and military installations to plunder and conquer.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, SCUM impresses with its detailed environments and realistic lighting effects. From dense forests to abandoned urban areas, each location feels different and immersive. The sound design further enhances the atmosphere, with ambient noise and environmental effects adding to the sense of immersion. However, occasional bugs and glitches can detract from the overall experience.

Combat and Interaction:
Combat in SCUM is intense and unforgiving. Whether engaged in close-quarters combat or long-range firefights, players must utilize cover, tactics, and skill to outmaneuver their opponents. The game's realistic ballistics system adds depth to gunplay, requiring players to consider factors such as bullet drop and weapon recoil. Additionally, SCUM has a strong interaction system, allowing players to communicate, trade, and form alliances with other survivors.

Community and Updates:
One of SCUM's greatest strengths is its active and dedicated community. With regular updates and fixes from the developer, the game continues to develop and improve over time. Player feedback is valued and implemented frequently, ensuring that SCUM remains a dynamic and engaging experience for both new and veteran players.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, SCUM sets a new standard for the survival genre with its complex gameplay mechanics, immersive world, and intense combat. While not without its flaws, the game offers a challenging and rewarding experience for those willing to take on the harsh post-apocalyptic landscape. With a dedicated community and continued support from the developers, SCUM remains a must-play title for survival game fans.

157115461.review:
I had purchased scum a couple years ago and at the time i was living somewhere with poor internet and that made this game difficult to play considering my connection speed, so I had left it in my inventory and maybe played solo a couple times.

Recently my brother and I were looking for a fun, somewhat grindy, PVE and some PVP games to play in the Open World Survival Craft genre, and I had remembered this game, and now I have much better internet. We have put several hours in so far and I will say we are enjoying this early access game.
Here are some thing we like and don't like about this game. 

Don't likes: 
At default settings, this game is WAY more grindy than most OWSC games I've played, but the solution is finding a server with an 8-10x loot modifier. 
The game can crash at times, and it's annoying, but luckily your character isn't idle in server time, so when you crash, your character disappears until you log back in. 
There can be some glitches at times: drinking or eating food straight from a box's inventory, can sometimes cause your characters ability to interact with anything disappear. Most of the time, a re-log will solve this issue. 
The most recent glitch me and my brother found is a random occurrence where our truck, while driving, no clipped through the map floor, we were spawned back on the ground, but our truck and all the loot from a bunker was lost to the abyss. 

Now the positives: 
This game is possibly the most accurate OWSC game in the gun department. IRL I am a gun nerd and seeing a game that implements correct loading animations for mags. drums, shotguns and also has accurate quantity counts (like 7rds. in a 1911 or certain shotguns have shorter feed tubes) is really cool and speaks to the research the devs have done. 
The complexity of crafting materials, or "grinding" to build bases, the inner-workings of vehicle mechanics, charging batteries, repairing guns with the parts of an identical gun and resource gathering restrictions (only carry 2 large logs at a time) are just a few ways this game immerses you into the survival mentality.

Don't let haters scare you off, but if you want the cleanliness of a AAA title then play a AAA title, but what I'll tell you is, I have not found a AAA title that itches all the spots of an immersive open world survival craft like this one. This isn't pay to win. Play with friends and enjoy a real walking dead world simulator where your day to day survival is based on how you maneuver through the challenges.

157636904.developer_response:
Hi bruteforceoap! We're sorry to see that you we're disappointed with the game. However, based on the points you've mentioned, we believe it would be best to address each of them in order to provide much needed clarity:

1. We're aware of the issue with rendering. The game still needs to be vastly optimized and we'll make sure to attend to that as we are nearing the full 1.0 release, which should improve this situation.
2. The overall loot of the game depends on where you are looking and whether someone that got before you looted the place which rendered you unable to find anything. There are spots, buildings and POI's on the map where you can find food that would help you sustain yourself. However, if that is also not satisfactory, you can also try playing on private servers where loot is vastly increased, meaning that it would be far easier for you to find new stuff.
3. You can bundle certain items such as short sticks, which are crucial for crafting initial items that can help you in the early game (such as the courier backpack that you've mentioned). It is intended that the starter clothes you have do not let you carry a lot of items as that makes you more inclined to loot and attempt to find better clothing and backpacks that will help you carry more stuff.
4. We've already touched upon this in point 2. The game is designed to not shower you with loot. However, if you prefer playing with a lot of it, there are private servers you can join that have drastically increased loot spawns so if that is your preference, you are free to try them out. 
5. Puppets are designed to be a real threat in the game. It is very hard to outrun them in an open field, and you also have to keep in mind that all puppets do not run at the same speed and that your stats, as well as the weight of items you are carrying, also have an influence your speed.
6. Your stats and the weapon you are carrying influence how difficult it is to kill puppets. However, by crafting either an improvised bow or a small stone axe, you should be able to get rid of them with ease.
7. We are looking into this system. Their number is not so much of a problem as is their spawning, which is something that we'll be tweaking in some of the upcoming patches.
8. We'll also be looking into this system to see if something can be done to make things easier for solo players. 

We hope that some of these will provide necessary clarification and that you'll consider giving the game another chance eventually or at least when we manage to bring it to the full 1.0 version.

153081472.review:
Short review-
buy it on sale 10-15 dollars, especially if you are ok with rust, and like zomboid. If you can't make it past the initial huge learning curve you won't waste too much money.


Longer review-
Recommending was a toss up. There is so much potential it is insane, and I do ultimately enjoy it, but there is a lot to unpack. 

Scum is the love child of Rust and Project Zomboid. Like Zomboid it has a steep learning curve. Very steep. If you are learning on your own, I estimate 50 hours if you have limited similar experiences to really have a grasp on how to survive, assuming you are learning most of the game and not skipping things.

Like Rust there is raiding and pvp, but it heavily depends on the server. Make no mistake 60 people on 1 server at once is a lot. Once you have the basics down, you can largely simplify the game if you please. You can sustain yourself on a simple diet, and you don't have to build or farm, and making money becomes easier. Many players live off of stashes they place in world and are baseless.

The way I see it the devs care about the game, but not about the players. This deserves further explanation. There are basically 0 quality of life features. If you want basic wood arrows, you need to cut sticks into small stick, then craft each arrow. Find a box of nails? Have fun right clicking and then left clicking remove nail for the next few minutes. That isn't fun, it is work. 

To add insult to injury there used to be faster ways to do it, like being able to craft a nail with the required material being a box of them, but that was removed for some reason. It is a simple recipe, it wouldn't take an hour to code it in from scratch, and if you just used a form it would take minutes. 

To make things a little more aggravating you need dozens if not hundreds of nails, bolts and bobby pins, which means you are unpacking for an hour of two if you do it all at once. Again, this is work, not fun. Further, your first base will likely be made with primitive gear, which means a simple 2x2 can take hours. 

Not very much is intuitive either, so it can be VERY frustrating. There are even keyboard commands that arent shown on the keybindings, which should piss anyone off. Because of this the game ultimately feels like the devs don't respect the players time which explains why the game is on life support.

In my experience official servers are more toxic than Rust official. The main reason is feuding. Some people hold grudges in rust, but the reality is that in rust there is usually such a high pop that are all doing the same thing, that people forget because in 30 minutes it happened again 2-3 times. Sometimes it goes further but I have yet to hear about long time players holding a grudge more than a day or two without a specific reason, like racism etc. Scum servers have to be smaller, so people will try to punish you specifically often. While this can be fun if it is a friendly competition, most people who are new don't want to deal with that. Ever have someone find all your bases and only raid you and constantly hunt for specifically you, before you were really established? I have it sucks, and there was literally nothing I could do. I was prim, and he had rifles. Why? apparently I built my first base too close to him, but I had no idea where he was. Maybe 2 hours in on my first time loading.

The actual gameplay is great, the animations are really good, plenty of things to do if you just want to learn playing solo. I do find the shooting to be the most accurate to real life than in any game I have ever played, with there being a bullet rise before drop, windage etc. So sniping can be really complicated compared to most other games, and in one case I hit a friend in the head with a shot at over a grid away. Unfortunately most servers wont have draw distance that high, but hey that happened and it was awesome. The hunting is incredibly hard, and the best way I can describe it is like spot and stalk irl, which isn't practiced a lot, and is quite difficult, harder than irl to be honest. Anyone who hunts knows hunting is not easy either. The fishing is fun. PVP is fast, as in incredibly fast. 1-2 shots and it is likely over, and even if you win, you could still die from the injury or infection. That is why server pops can not be too high.  

The game can be very fun after the learning curve, and there are many people who are helpful, and nice (relatively speaking, don't ask where their base is and they wont say goodnight). The online tutorials are ok, but until you figure it out do yourself a favor and start on a pve server. The game is immensely different than any other I have found, and you will need time to acclimate to it

Long version: SCUM used to be a good game, it had a ton of things to do and the devs continuously kept adding content to the game. You could play PvP, or go solo and even single player and have a more laid back experience crafting, cooking, hunting, building a base, fishing, etc. There were all kinds of vehicles to explore the map and it was a freaking fun game.

Unfortunately the devs have been taking features away, there were planes - gone, there were bikes - gone, there was a city you could explore – gone, there were cars, tractors, quads - all gone, even the birds are gone now. 

See, you used to be able to play SCUM the way you wanted, and you earned Fame Points for every action you did (it is supposed to be a game show after all), which were then used to respawn, from lower FP cost to respawn randomly on the map, to high cost to respawn at your shelter/base. With update 0.8 the devs introduced many new bugs and a money and gold system tied to respawn, basically SCUM is forcing you to play one way only if you want to have a chance to respawn and keep your character.

What a game of SCUM is now:
1. run around and loot
2. once you have enough loot, run around to find a trader and sell your stuff
3. run even more to find a bank or ATM to deposit the cash in your bank account
4. repeat 1 to 3 until you have enough to respawn (min $250 for a random spawn far away from your base)
5. repeat 1 to 4 to have enough cash to buy gold for an even better respawn choice:

From the store page:
- random respawn $250
- sector respawn $1000
- shelter respawn 1 gold unit

Oh and did I mention there are only 5 traders on the whole map? And if you are lucky to find that one modular car they added back, you will have to fix it first then push it all the way to a trader anyway to put in an engine. Enjoy that long walk.

Now, maybe some folks like to do this, but that is not what SCUM was, yet with update 0.8 the devs also had the brilliant idea to introduce PERMADEATH! Meaning that after 10 deaths (or if you reach -$2500) your character will disappear forever. So leveling your skills no longer means anything if you do not first run around looting to gather enough funds to keep your character alive!

After four years spent in Early Access the game still has many issues and definitely got worse this year, removing the vehicles was a major blow to playability. Yet the devs decided that the introduction of a banking system was a top priority. Which makes perfect sense if the game was ready to introduce a microtransaction system where cash for in game gold would guarantee you would never lose your character. 

Which brings me to this: as of 12/14/2022 Jagex aquired Gamepires. What means financial salvation for the indie studio also brings a sense of dread for us early adopters of SCUM. We all know Runescape and the microtransaction galore of its store page. Yet here we are. More worrying still is that bringing up the topic of the acquisition in the forums gets you warnings (for trolling, offensive content and spam), and the discussions get promptly removed, as if the topic was absolute taboo to talk about. (975 hours) The basic consensus is this game blows anything "similar" out of the water.
The developers are monsters. The updates are steady. The community is golden.

This is the most in-depth survival game on the market. You will meet people across the world and be able to do almost anything you can think of. There is a learning curve but I always am here to help noobs become pro. I was a server admin on some major servers and helped develop some hardcore PvE Survival Servers. Not the real premise, just some insight on this review. This game allows PvE and PvP so you can choose your play style. From where it began this game just gets less buggy and more amazing as it grows. Traders are new... allows growth at a faster pace than before. But onto the game. The combat is determined by individual servers. You can snipe from a distant hill, stalk players to their base, squad up and grow a killing team with all different attributes.

The map is beautiful, and I still don't have it down with almost 1,000 hours in game. This is the only game I've seen with a rolling weather system (wind picks up before a storm, clouds turn dark closer storm gets) and its my favorite "show off" factor. Sunsets/Rise are gorgeous.

Vehicles, planes, motorcycles, bikes, boats and bases. Build whatever you want, and craft pretty much anything with the right skills. Cities, towns, bunkers, vineyards, racetracks, quarries, hunter camps, airports, police stations, lighthouses, and docks are hand crafted beautifully. There are a ton more locations but from the freezing mountains down to the desert plains, it doesn't cease to amaze. You can hunt wolves, boar, deer, horses, bears and of course humans. Honestly I don't get how anyone can skip on this. Go fishing and then search an abandoned ship wreck. Go visit a castle in the mountains or hit the club.

Without the community Scum wouldn't be Scum. When you join a server, maybe you open a restaurant. Admins will host races and scavenger hunts. Some develop their own lore. Train new people to love the game like me. Collect every odd item. Have the biggest baddest squad, maybe the richest. I cant even begin to explain this game in one review. Just give it a go, but really dive into the game as a whole before knocking it.

DISCLAIMER: You will die. You will blow up your car. You will lose it all at some point. It is the point.
Collect backup gear, meet cool people, plan ahead and relax. Survival is key and no game tops Scum.
I bought this for 3 of my irl friends and they couldn't handle it. All my hours are lone wolf and I've met incredible humans across the world that became my friends.

Start looting more difficult POIs.  Dodge mechs to try to get a plane.  fall off the plane just as you're about to take off.  Strip off all your items so you don't drown. Go to outpost to sell loot.  Other players steal car.  Players harass you.  Set up squad mates to shoot harassers when driving on way out of safe zone.  Die, but your squad mates got the a-holes.

You missed a beeper at the gas station.  Die.  Respawn.  Get truck back before someone else.  Found another vehicle! OMG it's the police car! Carrying gas/battery/repair kit/lock.  Score.

Double dip at server resets.  Player walks in on you while lockpicking.  Shoot them in the face, but you've got a C4 now.  Where's my tourniquet!!! 

Find the a-holes base that crapped on your windshield.  Metal detector.  Find mines.  What do we need to blow down the wall?  Can't figure out lockpicking well enough to get through their doors.  Here they are - contested drop.  Shootout.

Respawn.  Make stone knife.

This is SCUM.

Just to preface this review, I have bought and played every "survival game" for the last like 5 years. I've been a server owner, modder, and clan owner on a myriad of survival games. 

That being said, this game is headed downhill fast. And it is not due to a lack of effort on the Devs part, they are doing a great job. I think the biggest issue this game has is direction. You need to pick right now what kind of game you are going to be. This game has all the mechanics and structure to be a great survival game, but it like all others before it is going down the dark path to being PVP centered. You can't stop PVP, but you can design in a way that makes it not break the game, and make all of the other great features irrelevant. 

Now all you have is groups of people running around the server killing everyone and running the bunkers so that it's damn near impossible to get any good loot unless you are running with a crew. The PVP is a joke as well, you and the other players chop and glitch and disappear entirely. And the PVP wouldn't be so bad if you could freely respawn somewhere, grab a weapon and get back in the fight. But you can't in this game. Dying means hours of running and looting just to scrap together enough gear to try again. Only to encounter another group of fully geared guys with sniper rifles hitting, and I'm not joking I can send you the video on this.. 1500m killshots. 1500m Killshots. What kind of survival game needs the ability to make 1500m killshots? And to add to the frustration, you have to BUY a respawn. So then you are out of fame points, cant do anything but random spawn and frantically loot again as you run AGAIN back to your base, then run AGAIN to a bunker or some high loot area, only to be killed by some douche that logs off in the bunker and shoots you in the back when he spawns in. There is so much broken gameplay with this game, and so many things that contradict each other it is unreal. Like the metabolism and levels.. I never look at that, ever. There is this huge part of the game, and it's a major part in a survival game that hasn't been done like this before. But it is rendered completely useless by the fact that people don't live long enough to even worry about it. Other than eating or drinking whatever random thing I had on me at the time, I never had a need to look at it any further. 

Farming? So you're telling me that in a survival game, where people are trying to scrape up everything around them to survive there is no farming? No gathering of wood and stone to build with? No building? And I know this is on the roadmap, but I think it needs to be made a higher priority. The majority of players on the server are solo or small groups that need a place to store their stuff, securely. This lockpicking thing is another issue. Whats the point of scrounging all this shit together in a base after spending 100's of fame points, that aren't exactly easy to come by, just to have your stuff lockpicked by another crew. Is that what surviving is about? Breaking into your neighbors house to take stuff that you don't even need? Like 6 man groups are running around lockpicking everyones houses and taking their guns and ammo. They don't need it, they have more than they could ever use. And then what is the solo suppose to do, start over at 0 and spend MORE fame points to board up the same house, or another one, just for it to happen again?

Cars - The clans control the cars. If you have one, they will take it. There is no way to lock them up, and very few buildings that you can actually store them in. And if you do, it will cost you hundreds of fame points. And even then, it can be easily lockpicked and stolen. Or you hit a couple trees with it due to the ridiculous handling and squirrely back end, and it blows up. Want to take it somewhere? Well you can, but when you get out you can't lock it. And people will generally follow you and take it. Cars should spawn all over the place, broken and in need of repair. They should require parts and fuel to run. You should have to gather these things up and fix the car to get it on the road. It should have keys that you can make for it. 
Broken.

Animals - You can't pack out a decent amount of meat after you kill an animal. Sure you can't pack out a whole boar in real life, but you could take say a shoulder or side of meat and throw it on your back. Then when you are back at your camp cut it up. Also why is there not just a grill I can make out of metal and place over a fire to cook meat on. I can get to the point where I have full military gear and weapons, but I am still putting meat on sticks to cook it?

There is all this opportunity for great immersion into a spectacular survival world but it is being quickly overshadowed by PVP and base raiding. It forces people to just give up and never come back. I'm not saying cut the PVP out completely, but at least find a way to balance it. Rust has tons of pvp, but you can spawn back in 1 of 10 sleeping bags placed anywhere in the world. Dying doesn't cost you anything, and you can have a base that isn't as easily raided to put guns in so you can get back in the fight. No looking around for clothes to hold gear in, as you have an inventory and everything takes 1 slot. They chose the PVP path, and the survival aspect is almost non-existent. If people want to battle royale let them play PUBG. That is not why I bought this game, and it is not what was promised when this all started. 

Make it about survival! Traps around your house, fishing, trapping game, building a place to call your own, picking herbs, making medicine, crafting things that actually have a purpose. Survival should mean more than surviving going in to a high loot area and not getting shot by another player. 

Balance PVP - You could make it so that if a player kills another player, the drone follows them around for a set amount of time showing their location to everyone or have a humanity system where they get negative humanity for killing another player and then loop something else into that like a bounty system. Random respawns should be free, but after 1 make it have like a 5 minute timer so people can't abuse it to travel around the map. Take out the high end snipers.. why why would you need that in a survival game? Balance the guns damage and armor rates. I got 1 shot full health, full military gear with a shotgun from 20 feet away, come on now. More hunting guns, less military grade weapons. After all, in a survival scenario that's what you would find more lying around hunting rifles, shotguns, and pistols. 

Stop focusing on putting more crap into the game, and fix the game that you already have.  Every item, feature, tweak you do to the game should be in line with wanting to push the game in a certain direction. Right now it seems like the dev team doesn't have a clear end game goal of where they want to be, and are just putting in things to try and get people to stay interested in the game with no regard to how it effects the overall gameplay. Or if at the end when everything is finished, it will even be the game we all paid our money for. Please. Please don't be the next Rust, or Arma. We have those already, and they are cancerous PVP games with terrible communities and aggravating play styles. Get a clear picture of what the final product is going to be, and stick with it. Number one because if you are just going to keep going this direction and end up just another PVP game, then people deserve to know now. Don't keep taking people's money and touting this game as a survival game with all these great survival features, only to produce a game that is just another PVP killing field. 

Overall this game has great potential, and the devs have done an amazing job so far. But I think that they need to pick a side and stick with it if they are going to be successful. If not then it will turn into another H1Z1, Miscreated, or Subsistence. Great games, that went nowhere.

I am going to split this review into three parts. 1) The good 2) The bad 3) What I think should be changed/added. 

1) The good:

- Beautiful world and elements
- Extremely realistic (uses real life logic with almost everything) 
- Food and nutrition system 
- Tonnes of places to explore
- Comprehensive list of items (Occasionally find things that I haven't seen yet)
- Lots of tiny details

2) The bad

- Frustratingly unclear learning curve (I learned how to play from Google and YouTube. Constantly need to search for how to do this and that. Tutorial is broken and incomplete)
- Extremely realistic (which is good but it can be really frustrating and boring at times)
- Laggy in big cities or during heavy rain
- Buildings are repetitive (can be expected of a big world but would be nice if they add more unique buildings)
- Crafting layout confusing and can't be searched

3) What can be changed/added

- SP is boring. Build up my defenses but no risk of attack at all. Would nice to have roaming hordes, or bandits. Someone to set off my alarms and traps or test my defenses. 
- Emotional health. Be the first game to account for player happiness. Like playing music, eating nice food, reading a book, catching your first fish, completing a big build will make the player happy. Things like recent death, death to a teammate, hungry, cold/wet makes player unhappy. Happiness affects speed and performance. No game has come close to being so realistic. Why not go for it? 
- Binoculars. I know maybe because of performance it's hard to zoom but would be cool
- Animal traps. I think you guys have tried this but it would be fun
- Treasure maps. SP is boring without goals. But imagine if during scavenging you come across someone's diary that has notes about where they hid their treasure, or maps to secret entrance to bunkers or tunnel
- Trader. I know it's not realistic for a trader to buy everything that you want to sell, but would be cool to have an economy. 
- Inventory system. Something like SHIFT click moves all of the same type. Also having your storage open you can double click for it to store directly. 
- Looting shortcuts. A hotkey for "pick up" or "pick up everything"
- Lots of random events. For example moving herds of deer, in SP have random dead bodies with loot like a crashed car, chopping down a tree sometimes you get a bird's nest with eggs, sometimes you get nuts/fruit....
- Middle strength AI enemies. Right now it's either crazy mechs or weakish puppets. Random patrols of reasonably killable mini mechs or mercs. Right now no one dares to attack mechs. But give us something to shoot at. 

I was so excited when I bought the game. But the first 4-5 hours I hated the game. It was so frustratingly hard and the tutorial didn't help at all. The game has it's logic but the learning curve is steep. Then I started to learn and enjoyed the game more and more. Then I got my car, tonnes of food, a raft, and it seems I ran out of stuff to do. Looting became a chore and repetitive. Life in SCUM became boring. I tried giving myself tasks to make it interesting. Right now I still like the game but it can be so much better. 44461658.review:
I’ll revisit this review periodically as I learn more and as things are patched. 


I've been tracking the development on this game for well over a year now and naturally have been eagerly awaiting Early Access to launch on Steam now for most of the summer. Yesterday that finally happened and I have to say that on the whole I am very pleasantly surprised!

I am a massive fan of survival games, even if I have become a bit fatigued with the constant stream of them over the last five years or so. But nevertheless, when Scum went live yesterday, I managed to get in just over 6 hours of gaming on it, both offline/single player and online with friends. I will say this review is perhaps a little premature in that respect as there’s still so much for me to find out about the game – actually that’s the first thing to note, there is  a LOT of content and a lot of game for an Early Access title . Much more than I expected and although there are bugs and issues (Early Access!), there’s actually a lot less than I expected.

Things that have impressed me so far:
-	Single player mode/standalone (great way for players to learn and to sandbox)
-	Smooth gameplay. The game runs relatively smoothly and very well even on my older system! There is some kind of memory leak bug that leads to FPS drops the longer you play presently but I expect that fixed soon. A quick game restart sorts it out anyway.
-	Lots of servers! Official regional servers are great!
-	Atmosphere and tone (It perfectly recaptures and represents the old Day Z feel but also adds some humour to it in places)
-	Content (Theres lots of loot and weapon and gear)
-	Body/Metabolism systems (Theres already a  lot of stuff in there in relation to the way your characters body works, but if you’re no into all that you can easily play without paying too much attention to it)
-	Map (The map is a good size considering these no vehicles yet – big enough to explore and get space, yet also reasonably spaced to easily find friends and get where you want to be relatively quickly. It also looks lovely!)
-	Hand to hand combat is pretty good but does need some further refinement
-	Inventory system (very similar to Arma2/Escape from tarkov!)
-	AI (enough AI antagonists to keep you on your toes and despite bugs like warping, pathing, not being able to open doors etc. they’re still a genuine threat)
-	Crafting (this is where the game excels, survivalists will cream themselves over this!)
-	There is a  match system in game that I admittedly haven’t used yet but looks good!



Bad things 
-	There are bugs and glitches, frustrating t times true. If this pisses you off, maybe wait to play till a few versions in.
-	A bit early to moan but no instant join on friends for multiplayer an the sever browser system isn’t working very well (at time of writing) as its difficult to find friends. 


Overall, this is everything Day Z should have been. Is it too late though? Nah, it’s an amazing game with so much potential. The devs have delivered a game Early Access that already knocks the socks off most rival games in the genre. Its exciting to think of how good this could actually be 6-12 months down the line! So far I’d say its more than worth the money!

Scum is definitely an Early Access game with lots of progress to be made before it can be called a "complete game".

Now that I have got that out of the way let's talk about why I recommend this game to everyone, including those that might not be into the survival aspect.

TL;DR:  SCUM is a game not just for your average survival player, the systems are complex and interesting, the environment is fun, and the devs are constant and listen to feedback.  If you are on the fence because the game is in Early Access all signs point to jumping over that fence and joining us on the island for some fun.

1) Complex systems:  The systems developed in SCUM have been put through the ringer by the devs, contacts the devs have made for accuracy, and also the players that have already purchased the game.  These are not simple systems that were rushed through production, they are detailed.  When shooting an arrow the game takes into account arrow rotation, shows arrow bounce/bend, and several other factors.  The metabolism system is the most detailed that I've seen and you can make your character get fatter, thinner, etc. based off how well you "play the metabolism game".

If that sounds like it's too complex for you then no worries, you can mostly ignore the details once you have figured out(or looked up) the way to maintain or properly utilize the systems and just stick to a routine.  The devs have put a ton of love into the game so it can be enjoyed by all sorts of fans.

2) Progress:  Progress has never stopped.  Sometimes it seems slow, sometimes you don't get the progress you want, but it is always constant.  This is not a game that the devs are going to abandon.  You can rest assured that the devs will give you some content updates periodically.

3) Base Building:  The map and base building seems to compliment one another.  Resources respawn at a rate that allows you to maintain a small outpost that is well hidden or building a impenetrable fortress out in the open for all to know your might.  Oh, you can also reinforce buildings and make that your home if you like.

4) Feedback:  The devs do listen.  Sometimes they listen to a group you disagree with but they do listen and their changes and updates are based off first the direction they want to go and second the groups that have been making the most noise recently.  The community has been clamoring for stability so that is what they have been working on the most with each update they release and things have been getting better.  The community has been consistent about wanting more single player content so the devs have been working on that as well.  Most recently a change the devs put in was widely disliked and they reversed it immediately.  As long as the desires of the community don't oppose the vision these devs have then its very likely they will try to work it in.

There's much I can say both positive and negative about this game but overall it is a worthwhile purchase.  If you're still on the fence after the above consider this(dated: 12/12/2019) after the winter sale on Steam the price will be increasing.  Now is the time to buy to get the best possible deal, the devs will keep adding more great content as they move closer to full release and the price will more than likely increase at least a couple times along the way.

Probably one of the [u]least[/u] competent development teams I've seen in the last two decades.  Reasons why I say this:
[list][*]They add a description and tags on the game's Store page for Single Player, Survival, and Co-Op.  None of these things have real content, either as in-game systems or valid gameplay modes (i.e. there's nothing to do in either SP or Co-Op beyond finding gear, killing AI 'puppets', or building a base which has no purpose).
[*]Having watched their team since mid-2019, I've seen them repeatedly promise things like a working metabolism system.  "It's being worked on, and will be here in a few months".  That statement was in 2019, and we're well into 2021 now with no working metabolism in sight.
[*]Single Player has zero goals or reasons to play it other than as a "primer to figure the game out for when you play PvP later".  It has 'puppets' (AI controlled zombies), that all use the same combat AI.  That's it, other than random animals and aim-bot Mechs (that aren't killable and don't add to gameplay).  No NPCs, no missions, no story, no goals of any kind.  Co-Op is exactly the same.  Beyond the first ~10-15 hours, there's nothing to do except explore or build (for no reason).
[*]"Fame points" that you can use to help you out in the game are setup purely for PvP acquisition.  You can get some by raising your skills in SP, but after that you have to actually kill someone in PvP to get more.
[*]They continually waste time adding in worthless items to the game.  Things like halloween masks, t-shirts, even socks for your willy (it's a guy thing)...  all manage to make it in before a core game mechanic like metabolism.[/list]

"Survival" is a set of game systems working together to keep you on your toes and make sure your character lives.  It has nothing to do with combat or enemies, and those are the only things in SCUM that threaten you in any way.  For that reason, there is "no survival in SCUM".

If you read the game's patch notes (all the way from the original release), you'll note a distinct lack of additions for anything except PvP.  Even new items and areas are PvP-centric.  I played for many months on a Co-Op server, and there was jack-all to do.  Run around, collect some gear, kill a few animals, then sit on your arse waiting for the developers to give us non-PVP'ers something to do. And they love to ban people on their Steam forums who point out that the promises they make are going unfulfilled.

tldr;  If all you want is battle-royale PvP, this might work for you.  If you want any game mode other than PvP, or a competent development team, definitely look at other games.  SCUM's store page is NOT an accurate description of the game [b]at all[/b], and the developers have been making promises and not living up to them for years now.  They've firmly taken the PvP-only route, leaving SP and Co-Op with virtually nothing to do.

107464402.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]
I cannot recommend this game for everyone. But I will recommend it for some.
I'll try and explain this briefly
So here's the thing, if you aren't into survival games, you probably wouldn't even be reading this review, but if you aren't familiar with survival games, you should probably go look into other games than this one not to scare you off, I recommend something easy to get to know like Rust. 
Now, to explain this to everyone else who don't know what the game is about, basically it's survival games taken to the "extreme" to be short. You have an excessive amount of options for maintaining your body and health. This includes vitamins, extensive cold/heat system and an very well done but also advanced weight system. I'll explain everything further in this review if this sounds interesting to you or if you're just bored. 
So lets start off with the positive(these could also be seen as negatives, depending on how much you're into survival games)

[h1] Pros [/h1]

A very extensive health system. You have literally have 13 vitamin bars to see how many vitamins you have been ingesting through the food and drink you either find, hunt or grow yourself. Adding onto this, you also have 10 mineral bars to make sure you're getting all your minerals. This is just [b]SOME[/b] of the things you have to take care of about your own body. The whole games is almost built around the "metabolism" screen. You have to make sure you eat healthy, go for a run once in a while etc, otherwise you get fat and get the negative things that come with that. I really don't want to go into detail more about what this whole metabolism system is on about, you can go watch YouTube tutorials for that or try out the game. 

You have a good variation in animals & enemies in my opinion. Boars, Cats, Wolfs, Bears, Sharks, Regular zombies, military zombies, suicide bomber zombies. Even robots! You can kill and eat basically any living thing in this game with the right tools, and regrets (looking at my cannibal homies)

Detailed world. The map isn't randomized like many other survival games, and the devs made sure to fill this with detail. There is an abundance of things to discover. I personally haven't played the game that long, but from what I have seen, each small town feels different enough compared to the other ones to give you a fresh feeling. The big city was a huge game changer when me and my buddy had spent over 40 hours in the same area/areas, making a base and getting better and better gear etc. We went to the biggest city not expecting much, but darn were we surprised. The graphics are also really good for a survival game, I half expected something like Rust or Ark that has this sort of "cartoonish" style to it.

It's best with friends, and enemies. I only played a bit of co-op with my friend, and this was sort of boring since we never found any other players cause we played on an empty server. This wasn't the most fun experience, but, I feel like it was a good way to learn the game together with someone. If I had to learn these gameplay mechanics myself, I would most likely get frustrated. I can understand why the singleplayer mode is in this, and it is helpful for people who unfortunately don't have other friends to learn the gameplay mechanics with on a server. And it would most likely get frustrating going into a populated PVP server and ending up getting owned by seasoned players who take advantage of you not knowing the game. When all that is said, this game is perfect for PVP. As I will get into riiiight

Now, gameplay. The shooting and weapon mechanics are extensive, not as extensive as in something like Tarkov, but it's very good. Bullet drop & travel, realistic ballistics (bullet penetration depending on material, weapon, ammo type etc), weapon degradation (I should state that basically everything in this game has degradation, bullets, food, scrap, clothing, everything). You might have a top notch condition shotgun all in perfect working order, but your weapon could still jam and f**k up your day if your bullets are in sh*t condition. This makes the game feel tense, cause anything could be the ruin of you at any time if you don't prepare extensively. Lemme tell you, having your rifle jam while there is a suicide zombie running towards you is [b]NOT[/b] something you want. And if you have a weapon that uses magazines then you will also have to manage their health. You'll have to reload magazines yourself before you can stick them in your weapon. Everything from aiming, weapon maintaining, running, weight carry etc all goes back to the previously mentioned metabolism system. Get your clothes wet? Well water weighs you down. That's straight up normal stuff you sometimes forget when playing survival games. Here, getting your backpack and all your clothes wet by going for a random or forced swim, or maybe an unlucky rain cloud hit you, this could all be the bane of your existence. You can only carry so much on your character, and it all depends on your metabolism, your strength, dexterity etc. So imagine you pack up as much as you can carry, you're already having a tough time just walking with all the stuff on you. And now a rain cloud comes, and you forgot your rain jacket. So now you just got maybe 30 kilograms of added water weight to your body. The main aspects this game wants you to remember is, prepare and maintain. This is why this game can be a really tough PVP game, cause everybody is on a struggle to keep themselves alive/in their best health. You can be a beast of a man, but you'll have the brain of a chicken. Or you can have a 900000IQ Reddit moderator brain, but you'll be as physically fit as a Reddit moderator. This all depends on how you choose to make your character to begin with, and how you choose to play. Intelligence affects a variety of things you'd expect, awareness, survival, engineering etc. Strength affects boxing, handguns, melee weapons etc. And then you also have dexterity and constitution. This can make this survival game almost RPG'ish. You can make a small shelter, and like in Rust, you can bury some storage chests if you have a shovel and want to live the rouge survivor style, where you have a small camp and stay in the forest hidden away. Or you can board up an existing house if you want to go that road. You can also, of course, build your own small - medium - big base of your own design. 

This is where I'll end on the positives since this review is getting long enough as is. On to the cons.

[h1] Cons/bugs [/h1]

Some of these will vary in how much of a con they are depending on what you want from a survival game
Medium to high learning curve. The whole metabolism part is just one of the things you'll need to learn to survive effectively in Scum. The PVP/PVE can get punishing as a result of the realism this game is trying to achieve.
There are of course bugs, first of all, the game is still in early access, so some things wont be working exactly as intended, I'll list a couple of bugs and issues I encountered in my as of writing this 58 hours of play time

-Zombies and animals glitching through objects such as wall and surfaces. ( Had 2 Wolfs enter my base through the wall, as well as a bear. Also when we went to the main big city, we went to the sports hall and zombies started appearing up through the floor. The glitching through objects thing was varying in when and where it happened. I never saw zombies glitching through walls, and through the floor only happened to me in the sports hall )
-A few things can feel unfinished, most likely due to the scope of this game. An example would be I had a very hard time finding a car battery that had any charge, and as far as I could find out there was no other way to charge a car battery without another car battery.

This is where I'll end my review as its already too long. But yea, pros pointed out in this review can also be seen as a con. Basically, it's DayZ. But good.

114176275.review:
TL;DR: SCUM was advertised to be a survival game. It was advertised with complex metabolism mechanics that required you to eat many different things to survive and thrive, realistic ballistics system, realistic movement mechanics and a varied martial arts system. SCUM has instead been dev't to be a fort building PVP game with little emphasis on survival and now a game wide easy mode from a forgiving and casual NPC trader makes it even less about surviving as getting anything (gear, food, weapons, building supplies) is very easy. 

So, another game with an identity crisis. The first year of SCUM was very problematic due to performance and lag issues, partly due to the devs choice to have only one locked server provider, known for its bad servers. During the 2nd year it started to be clear that the devs are adding more and more PVP focused features to the game. This was acceptable so there was some kind of basic gameplay loop that started to get a little bit more varied, but at the same time, it didnt really become varied. The devs added guns and vehicles in the game, followed with more complex basebuilding mechanics.

The base building mechanics seemed to take a big emphasis and following that most of the SCUM servers were very clearly PVP focused fort building gameplay style servers. To this day this is the majority of servers and its no wonder. Many players who looked for a survival game with a survival focused basic gameplay loop must have realised during the 2nd year how the direction for the game had changed. 

Recently SCUM had an update that added in-game NPC traders, airplanes and parachutes. The traders allow players to farm money with anything, like you can collect mushrooms and sell them to buy high-end weapons. This means that getting high-end gear and/or building supplies is easier than ever. It makes the game much more casual and PVP centered. Airplanes and parachutes are basically added for the basebuilder PVP style players as well, as those ones are the ones who will most probably access and keep a plane.

I bought the game day one, it was promised to be the most complex HC survival game with emphasis on things like metabolism and martial arts. Both are extremely bare bones mechanics to exist in a survival game in its 4th year of dev't. SCUM has got updates in a semi-regular manner - the updates have just been focused  way too much on base building and PVP mechanics. Even the weapons added have mostly been military themed weapons.

The metabolism system is due to have some sort of revamp, but no information on when. I personally think its too late already, the players who want a RUST with a few more things to eat (without any real consequence) and few less things to build have got what they wanted and the survival gamers have been forgotten about. You can survive very easily and having deficits in some vitamins or minerals have very little consequence. The ability to survive without eating while burning ones own reserves is more realistic than in DayZ for example, but that coupled with very plentiful food makes surviving a tertiary goal. Surviving... a tertiary goal.. in a survival game? Its sad, as there was a lot of potential for SCUM being a true survival game, one of the best.

The medical system in the game is very much bare bones as well. You can have different sorts of bleeds and thats about it. You cant break a leg, you cant get an infected wound from using dirty rags to bandage your wounds, you cant get cholera from eating contaminated water. You just bleed. The actual damage modeling from weapons is mediocre to good, the most protecting plate carriers protect maybe a little bit too much. There are conditions like hyperthermia and hypothermia, which is a good thing, but in the end its not enough. Experienced players just leave the clothes out and have all the tactical gear on them with little to no problems with temperature.

On top of all the gameplay issues and underlying identity crisis, SCUM is also still very poorly optimized, it has huge lag and desync issues on highly populated servers, making them even unplayable at times and so on. Its not recommended for anyone who wants a survival game. Its not recommended for someone who wants a more fleshed out DayZ, for example. It is recommended for people who want RUST clone with more things to eat and less things to build + a little bit more mature playerbase. We'll see if the devs ever address the identity crisis, their mods seem to think that only overwhelming hate against sth is enough to warrant an answer - or a change.

The only thing it is missing is a game.  I have had scum for a while and have put some hours into it, myself and some friends revisited it a couple of days ago after a long break so thought I would put together a review.

We played for about 3 hours straight on a server with just under 50 players.  That time consisted of the same thing playing scum always does, running.  We all spawned in on opposite sides of the map because there is nothing more fun than starting a new game with 30 minutes of auto running.  We met up at the new (to us) city in the NW corner, after looting generic crap from the city we moved on to the Sanitarium as it was marked as high loot on the map we were using.  More generic crap loot.  So we went to a nearby bunker, snuck past the mechs who seem to be more broken than the last time we played but just a dull an uninteresting. 

We looted up and found a few guns, no matching mags though.  We suffered a couple of deaths, one guy glitching off a ladder, another guy threw a ninja star at a wall and it bounced back and killed him (admitredly pretty funny).

We moved on to another bunker, snuck past the glitchy mechs, more generic loot etc. etc.

At which point people were bored it had been 3 hours and nothing had happened, we hadn't seen any people, no puppets, nothing.  I have recently checked out Deadside which is kind of a Scum lite game.  Whilst I feel that deadside may be a bit quick to garner long term enjoyment the pace of Scum is ridiculously slow.  3 hours of looting and not a single gunfight or action of any kind.

This "game" needs a lot of game adding to it if it wants to be fun.  It has puppets but they seem so rare that they might as well not be there.  The map is way too big for the 50 players supported on official (upto 100 players on other servers).  Based on the size of map you will have about 3 players per huge square which means the odds of running into people, even at POIs is slim.

I think this game really needs more ai enemies, ideally human ones with guns not just puppets/zombies.  These ai would provide; something to do, more interesting looting than endless crate searching and a catalyst for action.  The AI in deadside for example are very basic, but relatively fun to shoot at.  More importantly though, when you get into a gun fight it makes noise, which can draw in players, which in turn brings in more players and before you know it you are in a multi team war.  This just doesn't happen in Scum, the player numbers, map size and infrequency of gun fights means it rarely gains momentum.

The base building is painful at best, the bulk of it is ok, not as satisfying as other games out there but not the worst I have seen.  The locking system though is dire.  Rather than making a lock from things you find you make it from fame points, which you earn from doing random activities within the game.  It is a deeply dissatisfying system which leads to you having to grind pointless stuff like crafting bone needles to get points.  These locks can also be picked using a skyrim esque lock pick mini game which once mastered makes (tbf its cancerous and painful to master)  the locks easy to get past.  Ultimately this feature turns the building into a painful and futile exercise and that's before you consider that there is not much point in building a base anyway.

Ultimately Scum is an incredible, intricate platform with advanced and detailed mechanics, but there is virtually no game play.

Can I recommend it?  I don't know what there is to recommend so I guess that's a no.  Someday they may add in some mechanics to make the game fun but I am not holding my breath.

47941719.review:
DISCLAIMER:  This review is accurate as of 12/29/18.  SCUM is a rapidly changing Early-Access title, so any or all of the information in this review is subject to change.

Let's get this part of the way first: Do I recommend SCUM to anyone expecting a finished product?  Absolutely not.  Many features of this game are bugged, missing, or clearly unfinished (several aspects of character creation, illnesses, and a good portion of the nutrition system, to name a few).

With that out of the way, I can say that Gamepires has already done more in a few months than the Day Z Standalone team did in four years.  Even in its barebones, unfinished state this game is a much more polished product than Day Z ever was.  However, a number of features do make this game distinct from Day Z and other similar games.  

The biggest difference is in the character customization.  SCUM uses an attribute and skill system similar to an RPG to determine both your character's overall physical build and what they're good at.  Though many skills have yet to be implemented properly, there is already some great potential in what's there.  Furthermore, the devs seem like great people and have been very diligent at providing regular hotfixes, dev diaries, and response to feedback.  As someone who has been turned off on early access titles in the past, this was a breath of fresh air that ultimately pushed me into giving the game a try.

Combat is about what you'd expect from a game like this: conserve your ammunition, avoid combat with Puppets (the "zombies") whenever possible, and make sure to keep your wounds treated.  However, once you get the crafting system down, it becomes quite a bit more forgiving than other games.  Spend your scarce starting resources right and you can have a small backpack, bow, and stone axe within minutes without even leaving your spawn area.  

Once you find a gun, you can expect similar bullet physics to milsim games like ARMA.  Bullets have travel time and drop, and can punch through materials depending on caliber and distance.  Recoil and spread can be reduced by your strength stat and skill in that particular weapon type.

Graphics and performance are both quite good in my overall experience, especially for such an early build.  My 1080 has not dropped below 60FPS on high settings.  There is occasional hitching when the game is loading new areas, but nothing game-breaking.  The graphics aren't revolutionary, but they're quite nice as well, with some excellent details here and there (my favorite so far is a very cool light-shaft effect from the bullet holes if you're getting shot at inside a building).

Overall, if you don't like paying for an obviously unfinished product, hold off on SCUM for now.  However, if you're looking to scratch that survival game itch and want to support the development of a game with some serious potential, SCUM is worth a go.

Scum is a visually beautiful game with amazing graphics, even though the game is still only in early access and hasn't been fully optimized. However, for those creative people out there, there are still things that Server owners and admins can implement or change to adapt their server's gameplay. As someone who has about 1000 hours in DayZ, I can confidently say that Scum will likely be the only Zombie Survival game I will play going forward since discovering it in August of 2022.
